Definition: In this task, you get a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: toxic and non-toxic. Toxicity is dismissed as anything that is rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable that would make someone leave a conversation.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: Although it is not true that all conservatives are stupid people, it is true that most stupid people are conservative.

 John Stuart Mill
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a toxic comment because it is disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Why? You just wasted  5 minutes of my life.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a non-toxic comment because it is not rude or desrespectful.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: I personally know and work with Muslims. None of them cover their faces.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be non-toxic because the comment only speaks about muslims but does not disrespect them.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Glenn, why are you such a fool. Grow up!
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be toxic because it disrespects Glen.

Comment: Caleb said :"By adopting a written system of language, the Hawaiian people opened themselves to thinking English. Although phonetically the Hawaiian language was still the same, a relationship was established between the English and Hawaiian language, for the ultimate purpose of indoctrinating the Hawaiian people into Western schools of thought."  

What he failed to mention is that the absence of a written language and its importance in recording historical events lead to willy-nilly historical revisionism based on political point of view and wishful thinking. In the present, the "loudest voice in the room prevails" type of leadership can still be seen in community meetings here in Hawaii.

It is of little consequence (other than in commerce and government) what language is spoken, as long as it has a foundation in the written word.  Political discussions are meaningless if there is no basis in writing to accurately judge what has happened in the past.

Comment: You do know what a control group is for right?   It is what you compare against what you're studying.  

Now you ask what do you need to know about head start?  Head Start is a program of the U.S..Dept of Health and Human Services that provides comprehensive early childhood education, health, nutrition, and parent involvement services to low-income children and their families.  Eligibility is largely income-based, although each local program includes other eligibility criteria, such as disabilities and services needed by other family members. Families must earn less than 100% of the federal poverty level.

In overall,  the study says it doesn't matter if you went to preschool or not.  Most of the children by the 3rd grade showed no significant positive impacts on math skills, prewriting, promotion, or teachers' reports of children's school accomplishments.  

Bottom line,  If you want your children to do good in school,  parent involvement is important.

Comment: What a load of cods-wallop.  Those in the temperance movement, and make no mistake, that's exactly what MADD is - a temperance movement,  are fond of using scientifically unsound catch-phrases such as "Impairment Starts With The First Drink."  The author of this piece is cut from the same cloth.  

Unless we have 0.00 as the only acceptable Blood Alcohol Content, then we must by definition, establish a BAC level beyond which one is considered impaired.  Which means in the converse, below that limit, one is not considered impaired.  It must be set at some level.  

There is no basis upon which to justify a change to 0.05 from 0.08 as being that ideal limit.  This is completely a political decision, not borne of research, science or evidence.  

Wasn't it Trudeau who pledged "evidence-based" decision making in his government?  What a hypocrite!

Comment: Indeed. In a nutshell, this is our own particular society crept up on Utopia's Horizon: Think deep and you will realize that relatively-free & intelligent mankind had only one destination - a society where all menial labor (even Dr.s / lawyers) is executed by artificial-lifeforms. I've never been a fan of or watched Star-Trek, but their look-ahead in many aspects is dead-on. IBM was able to manipulate single atoms and arrange them to their will 20 yrs ago; Crick & Watson have their names on the DNA assembly gear; the need for human-driven-labor diminishes at an exponential rate, and that IS and has always been the unconscious if not conscious goal of technical progress. Food is not much more than novel combinations of atoms and it's totally plausible in the next 100yrs to have Food-Generators basically 3D-printing food. We are getting closer to one facet of an utopian ideal, now we just have to somehow gently convince people that the earth can only support -X- number of occupants...

Comment: In 1934, with the enactment of the Indian Reorganization Act (25 U.S.C.A. § 461, et. seq.), Indian tribes were allowed to exercise their inherent sovereignty to establish their own justice codes and operate court systems enforcing those laws. The Act authorized tribes to organize and adopt constitutions. However, many of the tribally-enacted constitutions were boiler-plate templates, requiring Secretary of the Interior-approval for many tribal government actions. Nevertheless, despite its flaws, the Act is considered a “success” in providing a framework for and first-step towards expanding tribal self-government. www.tribal-institute.org/lists/justice.htm

Comment: The Affordable Care Act received no Republican votes in either the Senate or the House of Representatives. In the Senate, the bill was passed with a total of 60 votes, or 58 Democratic votes and 2 Independent votes. The House passed the legislation with 219 Democratic votes. 

Now it seems the Republican Party intends to pass rival legislation with no Democratic support. Both scenarios put the American people at risk of losing their health insurance, but both parties continue to treat health care as a game they must win instead of a greater good for which they must compromise. 

The relevant precedents are Roosevelt's passage of Social Security and Johnson's passage of Medicare, each of which received significant cross-party support. If our Congress doesn't put aside their ideological differences, we will continue to sacrifice the good to the perfect, and the American people will continue to be victims every time Congress changes hands.

Comment: Note to ignorant Associate Press and the equally ignorant Denver Post Editorial Staff. Micronesia isn't a country. Micronesia is a sub-geographic area in the Western Pacific. The U.S. Territory of Guam is part of Micronesia.  The Federated States of Micronesia are comprised of Yap, Chuuk, Pohnpei, and Kosrae. 

Moreover, it's the Republic of Palau. It's not a group of islands. It's a sovereign nation. Palau gained its independence on October 1, 1994. Some Americans would recognize the ferocious WWII Pacific battle of Peleliu. Peleliu is one of the states of Palau. When you visit Peleliu, you'll see beautiful memorials to the 2k+ U.S. Marines, Navy, and Army service members who were killed. You'll also see beautiful memorials to the 10k+ Japanese who died in the battle. Palau lost 10% of its population to WWII. Yet the Palauans respect the dead from both sides despite the immense tragedy. If they were Americans, they'd already be tearing down the memorials to the dead.

Comment: It is important to broaden the idea of storage to help people understand that the use of renewables is not as hard as some try to make it.  For very low cost or zero fuel cost generation such as renewables storage has always made sense. Xcel build storage as have most of the nuclear generators because there need it and there is very little cost as when one needs to burn fuel. Pumped water storage has been economical and now that Xcel needs more they are expanding their pumped water storage.
Other technologies such as phase change/thermal mass is use to shift load by storing cold during nonpeak hours. Thermal solar can store heat during the day for use at night or on a cloudy day.
Hydrogen in various forms is a very likely major storage mechanism.
Modifications to the current grid structure will make it more robust and solve many problems that current structure imposes. Use of minigrids and UHVDC grid structureneeds to be given thought.

Comment: I'm sure you've got a source for your claim. My claim was based on the draft rule.

But here's the thing: the mandate was not approved by Congress. It was devised by the Obama administration. Nothing in the ACA actually requires the mandate, but the HHS retains the discretion to impose it. So, in theory, it could go away. But this draft rule does not propose completely eliminating the mandate, simply allowing exceptions for religious and moral reasons. Claiming any business could object to the mandate for "any reason" is overstating your case. 

I don't think the mandate is worth more years of litigation, especially since the government keeps losing. And as I said, most plans will continue to cover them. As Therese points out, if you want contraceptives, don't go to work for nuns. Work elsewhere.

Comment: While there may be a problem with overcharging for some drugs that's not necessarily the case for drugs that are designed to treat extremely rare diseases.

On average it costs $1 billion (US) to bring a new drug to market.  Research, clinical trials, and the approval process itself are hardly inexpensive - the company has to recoup those costs so don't expect things to be cheap.

But when you shift the focus to truly rare diseases (the ones where there are less than 100 known sufferers in the world) how can anyone expect the price to be "low"?  And, if the manufacturer can't recoup their costs why would they consider investing in the development of these drugs?

Comment: I'm confused by my reading about the US estate tax repeal.

I understand estate tax to mean beneficiaries being taxed on inheritance received. It that right?

But I also understand the this so-called "death tax" repeal with create a new tax shelter for the living -- capital gains earned while alive are not taxed at death, either in the hands of the estate or in the hand of beneficiaries. Properties and stocks subject to capital gains can be bequeathed without the estate paying the outstanding tax  increased value, and the the deemed purchase value of these properties/stocks in the hands of  beneficiaries is reset to current market value. Is that correct?

In Canada we have never had an estate tax, and we have a simple rule that ensures all taxes on income earned while alive is paid--at death, anything subject to capital gains is deemed to have been sold on the day of death, the the deceased's terminal tax return (not the estate return) is taxed on the gains from those deemed sales.

Comment: It may be true that the Democratic Party's love affair with neoliberal economics has caused it to neglect its traditional constituencies among the working class and labour in favour of educated city dwellers. Still, at least Obamacare made a nod to addressing the needs of America's working poor and lower classes. 

However, there is no place in a Republican America for the working poor and those who are down on their luck. Trump employed the typical bait and switch move: he mobilized racist and nationalist animus among the white working class and dangled promises of a return of fantasy jobs. Then Trump released a vicious budget that will attack the poor while he proposes to gut Obamacare and leave 20 million people without medical coverage. 

Moreover, I'm no fan of Clinton, but the whole "deplorables" quote is entirely defensible: she was using the word deplorable to describe that contingent of Trump's supporters who are racist, sexist and bigoted — those who are indeed "deplorable."

Comment: Dan Tucker - If you study the writings of the Founders, you will find that they created exactly a system that would run to gridlock. They wanted government to endlessly debate issues and pass only a small amount of legislation because why government was preoccupied with this task, people could get stuff done without the interference of government. Our Founders rightly distrusted government deeply ... with a few exceptions. Alexander Hamilton wanted a king. He thought monarchy was a more efficient form of government, so he made sure the presidency had a lot more power than most of the Founders were comfortable giving to a single "ruler".

For about 100 years, we have been force fed this nonsense that government is supposed to be efficient and pass laws, but that's just meant that we're all drowning in laws to where our society can't function anymore. I see the current "gridlock" as a good thing. Now, if we could just sunset about 90% of the laws, the people can get stuff done.

Comment: I've known, over the years, many religious sisters, both as teachers when I was young and as friends and colleagues when I was older. I cherish my memories of their dedication and service and I am thankful for all they gave me.

That said, I often wonder whether the future of consecrated life will be found in religious orders, male and female. Those constructs were created in a certain time and place and they served their purpose, but the world changes. New models emerge.

My best guess is that vowed, celibate religious communities will survive and will still serve a valuable purpose in the Body of Christ, but I doubt they'll ever be as robust as they once were. If so, that won't necessarily be a bad thing. It'll just be a reality.

Comment: See previous post. This is the 2nd of two proposed poll questions for the next Civil Beat poll on rail: 

2) According to the City’s Environmental Impact Statement, traffic congestion will be worse in the future than it is today, even if rail transit is built. The final EIS, which spells out the details of the rail project, is thousands of pages long. That is why it is crucial that public polls on rail include basic, undisputed facts in the questions they pose to respondents.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees. Comment: My reference to the Evil One was merely to make the point that not all developments are positive for two reasons, human and evil; I did not in any way implicate Satan is this issue.

I do not content that adoration ought to be denied those who find solace therein, but merely that it, IMHO, is not a felicitous historical development in its historical context, and that alone is reason enough to ponder whether it ought to be fostered or allowed to wither today. We will disagree on that one.

Re ecumenism, I am working from an unstated image of how Christianity might grow back together again. I take the plaintive cry of Jesus on the eve of his crucifixion that "We may be one" to be a moral imperative for all Christians, and I suggest that if every group were to strive to grow together by putting aside peripheral practice and peripheral theology, we might indeed one day once again become one as Jesus wishes. Benediction is, IMHO, just such a peripheral practice.

Comment: "It may be that the US is ceasing to be a great and enlightened country..."

So the myth goes.  "Great"?  In industrial terms, up to about 50 years ago, no question. Those times are gone, for a variety of reasons, and will not return for generations--if at all.  In military terms?  No question.  Until, again, about 50 years ago, when America's US Marines-led conquest of foreign lands ("From the halls of Montezuma to the shores of Tripoli...") started to fault and fail. 

Enlightened?  Rarely.  Not that Americans were stupid.  They--like Canadians--remained blissfully unaware, for the most part.  Uninformed rather than ill-informed.  The advent of electronic media (radio/TV/the web) was to change all that.  It hasn't.  Now Americans are--like many Canadians--both uninformed AND ill-informed.  

 "...you may be more concerned about making America wise again."  History tells us that many times, neither Canada nor America was 'wise' at all.

The piece illustrated is one of those social justice pieces. Pistoletto has other sculpture much more in tune with classical vibes. Italian art is among the greatest on Earth, for all times. Comment: Day
‘I am busy’ said the sea.
‘I am busy’ Think of me
making continents to be.
‘I am busy” said the sea

‘I am busy’ said the rain.
‘When I fall it’s not in vain;
Wait and you will see the grain.
I am busy.’ Said the rain.

‘I am busy” said the air,
‘Blowing here and blowing there,
Up and down and everywhere.
I am busy,' said the air.

‘I am busy,’ said the sun.
‘All my planets, every one,
Know my work is never done.
I am busy, said the sun.

Sea and rain and air and sun,
Here’s a fellow toiler – one,
Whose task will soon be done.


“Poetry”
“Day” by Sir Cecil Spring Rice

Comment: The softwood lumber matter has always been a sticky one. It's caused by the fact that mills in some parts of Canada get most of their timber from crown land. They pay "stumpage" fees to the respective provinces to harvest  trees. Some provinces, most notably BC, have been accused by the Americans of charging  below market rates; which is considered an unfair trade advantage. They have a strong case. I'm posting from a province where most of the land is privately owned and stumpage is sold at market rates which are several times higher than the BC crown rate creating a situation that  adversely affects local (Canadian) mills that have to pay full market prices for raw material. 
This festering dispute remains to be settled.

Comment: I'm reminded of that landmark paper: _The Basic Laws of Human Stupidity_ by Carlo M. Cipolla, Former Professor of Economics at University UC Berkeley.

-First Law: Always and inevitably everyone underestimates the number of stupid individuals in circulation.
-Second Law: The probability that a certain person be stupid is independent of any other characteristic of that person.
-Third (and Golden) Law: A stupid person is a person who causes losses to another person or to a group of persons while himself deriving no gain and even possibly incurring losses.
-Fourth Law: Non-stupid people always underestimate the damaging power of stupid individuals. In particular non-stupid people constantly forget that at -all times and places and under any circumstances to deal and/or associate with stupid people always turns out to be a costly mistake.
-Fifth Law: A stupid person is the most dangerous type of person.
-Corollary to the 5th Law: A stupid person is more dangerous than a bandit.

Paul

Comment: EN,  I see it as a way to strengthen the party system.  The parties would now provide the continuity and the parties would be responsible for presenting viable candidates who can and will get things done in one term.  Additionally, a party strategy for this new reality could be to mentor a "like" third party to develop replacement candidates.  Additionally, a candidate elected in election A would be eligible to run again in election C.  We could see an Oregon federal representative or senator move back to an elected Oregon state representative, senator, or some other local position.  Talk about being in tune with one's constituency and state needs!  Folks would let that congressman know in the local election if they liked what he/she did.  Not voting for incumbents would be a Citizen's "do it yourself" term limits that would still be Constitutional and require no ruling from the courts.  It would be the People by-passing Congress and the courts to get things done.

In the second place, I define justice as giving something their due--what they are owed.  No one is owed the Sacraments. The Sacraments are gifts. Therefore I do not see how one can claim they are entitled to any of the Sacraments, let alone ordination.

In any case, in order to claim that the Church teaching on women is unjust, you have to prove that God is calling women to ordination in the first place--and THAT, sir, is the question.  THAT is what is at issue.

Comment: Hmmm.  Seems there was a UAA study about 20 years ago looking at the use of polymer-modified asphalts in our roads.  The results indicated that compared to non-modified asphalt they were more durable, were more pliable at lower temperatures (which prevents cracking and potholes) and had a higher melting/softening point in the summer.  As to studs causing ruts in the road?  It is during the summer when ruts are formed.   Heavily-loaded tires on hot, soft asphalt cause them.  In the winter, studs just scratch the road surface when folks stop and go at intersections.  If AKDOT had mandated the use of these plastic compounds in our roads it would have increased the cost of roads by 10%, but.. they would've lasted much, much longer. With fewer ruts.  Canada switched over to polymer-modified asphalts for that very reason and they've had great success.  Sounds like a safety issue, Senator.  The revenue you bring in isn't worth a single life.  How about looking at a long term solution.

Comment: Blaming/Lauding  individual anecdotal spending and/or lifestyle choices misses the economic point. 
This is a widespread problem with a provable, statistical result much like 2008. 
Fact: Wages have stagnated or gone down for a decade. The cost of living, relatively, has gone dramatically up, especially housing, hydro and the like. Canadians are more indebted than ever before even though many have cut costs or gone without certain items. 
 This kind of economy relies on debt, not efficiency for growth. It is unsustainable in the long term.

Comment: I'm trying to guess what the purpose of having the test in the first place was?    Why have a test if nothing is done with the results?

Swimming IS a life-skill, but having raised two competitive swimmers - have to say that there are not a lot of available pool facilities in the GTA (for the size of population) and learn to swim programs from the City of Toronto are filled quickly.    Private instruction is expensive.    So many Canadians never learn to swim beyond staying afloat for a  few yards.      Further - many immigrants 
 to Canada come from areas where swimming is not considered a necessary life-skill.     This makes the swimming test all the more important.

I can sort of understand the pressures that the teachers probably faced to be inclusive for this trip to happen - but it had tragic consequences.    So the one good that may come of this tragedy is more adherence to testing and the results as well as proper instruction.

Comment: Actually, the idea that all hospitals (even rural ones) will provide all services is the red herring.  If you suffer a brain hemorrhage, your local hospital will diagnose your condition and send you on to the nearest major centre - which may be hours away.  Similarly, if you have a terminal illness, you won't be dealing with It at a rural facility.  Hence, no need for rural hospitals to provide assisted death.

Your second point is an argument against your position, not for it.  Competency in end-of-life management is not trivial, and thus skills and equipment will be concentrated at one hospital in a major centre, just as oncology services are.

You and Mr. Picard want to make this about values, but it's not.

Comment: Indeed you're right it's not the optimal time for sexual fulfillment for women. Generally speaking ovulation would be the time that a woman most desires sex and finds enjoyment in it. And wouldn't ya know that's precisely the thing that the Pill suppresses! 

And don't play the "you just equated contraception to nuclear war!" card. It's the use of an extreme example to drive home an reasonable principle. Here's a more palatable example: the "white lie". The person who thinks intention is the dominant factor in moral action would say that a white lie is morally fine because your intention is to spare someone's feelings or make them feel good. Solid intention but doesn't change the nature of the moral act which is speaking falsehood. If I ask my wife if I look stupid with a particular shirt on and I objectively do look stupid and she tells me I don't, her desire to spare my feelings doesn't change the fact that she lied and I am going out in public looking stupid. Same logic as before.

Comment: Good questions Paul, and I didn't, in my opinion, hit the bullseye on this issue. Too bad, you get one shot on the forum. But it is an interesting proposition that Mansfield makes. However I still think it is transparently bogus. Maybe you make choices from "the gut" or from "the heart", two organs that don't think; but we are responsible in the end to make decisions based on real truths, not perceived truths.

Are people inherently good or inherently bad? Neither. We are a species of animal, a highly tribal animal; and conflict I suspect has always been resolved by violence. The crazy person so judged by the tribe is stoned, crucified, or burned. The witch is killed with a stake through her heart for casting spells, causing children and cattle to die, or rains for crops to disappear. However we also have sympathy for others and take care of them, and bury them with flowers when they die. But are we good for the other creatures? For the yet to be born? What's the answer there?

Comment: Amusing that she is blaming OCS for this entire problem...these children that are being "kidnapped and kept illegally" all have court cases assigned to them.  With that court case comes an attorney to represent OCS, an attorney to represent the child,  a guardian ad litem who watches out for the best interests of the child, and a judge/magistrate who oversees the court case.   There are multiple layers involved in a Child in Need of Aid (CINA) case that ensures rules are being followed.  If a child is being detained illegally, I would look to the judge/magistrate that signed the order allowing custody, to the assistant attorney general who has to defend the actions of OCS,  and to the child's attorney and GAL - not just the OCS worker.

Comment: I'm visiting in coastal Washington State for the first time in a few years, and buying groceries and household items. I've definitely noticed their shopping bag tax - apparently on both plastic and large paper - frankly I've been too busy to glean the tax particulars -- but I have observed the natural economic behavior changes among my fellow shoppers!      Observations?  First,  more people than in Anchorage are bringing their own bags with them - The dime-per-bag levy HAS -at least from my personal observations -significantly reduced Washingtonians' consumption of plastic - and paper - bags among shoppers. Paper bags seem to be taxed at a lower rate - or the paper bag fee not be a tax- just a store cost-recovery mechanism - again I've not yet explored the tax structure -- my observation is that it is clearly reducing plastic bag consumption - and is raising tax revenues that may or may not be targeted to litter cleanup. And local consumers seem accepting or even supportive!

Comment: A problem with statistics like these, and the inferences drawn from them, is that they do not take into account the starkly different people groups within the US. Asian countries are, by and large, genetically heterogeneous (look at Japan, for example), as are many European nations. The genetic diversity of the US should be taken into account, as well as the rates of obesity associated with certain people groups. Poverty, low education levels, and genetic ancestry (as well the combination of the three) are clearly associated with obesity. Until that is recognized, any attempt to throw federal tax money at America's "obesity problem" is bound to fail.

Comment: Did you GRAB his hand from his side ? Because that would, indeed, be assault (or possibly battery - the differences are subtle and only really important to lawyers). But if you held out your hand, and he reached out to shake it, then he DID consent to that contact.

Consent doesn't have to be verbal. If you claim non-verbal consent, the court will judge on testimony whether it was reasonable to interpret the actions of the person as consent. If he pulled his hand back, and you grabbed toward it-  you'd be guilty. If he shook yours - you're fine.

Much as - if you grab a woman and kiss her, that's usually sexual assault. If you stop a few centimeters away, and wait to see if you she comes in and kisses you back - then it is consensual. You tried to commit a reductio et absurdium fallacy, but all you managed to do is be silly. If you intended to show that the law is silly, then you failed, because it's not as your silly example is entirely legal.

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

The guidance is simplistic and impractical -- might as well not vote.

Given the clear choice in this presidential election, the only defensible rational for voting for a third-party candidate is to make some kind of "statement," under the assumption that you _might_ be among a significant enough group to gain attention and effect the future in a positive way.

However, helping elect Trump would be an extremely costly way to _maybe_ slightly increase the impact of Sanders campaign (which has been substantial).

Not a smart move. The calculus is simple: A net negative impact if Trump were elected because of a third-party vote.

-- Paul

Comment: There are many pieces of evidence.  Take a look at Area: The forestry industry claims it wants to be sustainable, yet, after 150years of timber extraction in this country, why do forestry companies continue to push further and further into new territory -- often crown land.  Why is it not possible for them to use the forests they already have? Because they can't and remain profitable at the same time. Second, Why are sensitive species that require high quality forest like Woodland Caribou and Spotted Owl now threatened? Third - forestry companies are subsidized because they don't pay very much for the use of the land -- far less than if they owned it. Taxpayers pay for this.  Forth - all this and the decline in the number of jobs and value added products means Canadians don't benefit. If you want a good model of forestry and forest product manufacturing, look to Finland.

Comment: The IEP programs for dysfunctional students are on a continuum of services...from mild to very severe....at the severe end....placement in a residential treatment facility...and, yes, it does happen.  

IEPs are reviewed and "changed" if necessary.  A student may move to a more restrictive setting and program if needed OR move to a less restrictive setting and program if merited.  The goal being, hopefully, at some future date, the student's reintegration into the "regular" school program.  Indeed, schools need to consider the disruption caused by dysfunctional students in developing and, when needed, modifying IEPs.  If a student is disrupting the education of other students, at some point, that student does, as you suggest, need to be removed from the classroom.  It's important to provide opportunities for growth and improvement, but not at the expense of the other students.  regards, Gary Crum

Comment: Losing a loved one is always difficult.  It seems to me that it would be hardest for the parents of a child and also for young children losing a parent.  Thankfully, I have never been faced with the death of a child, and I was an adult (although barely) by the time that my mother died.  So, even though that was hard, it was much, much different than it was for my significantly younger brothers who had just entering their teens.  
However, I think that a part of the problem in the US consists of the fact we don't speak of death and treat it as something foreign to life.   I think this makes it so much harder for us to deal with death when it comes.  I think that the hard decisions that need to be made are so much easier when people do as your mother did and make their wishes known to family members.
I realize that this does not apply to children, who are a special, heart-wrenching situation.

Comment: Again ... relevance.  Whether it's whimsy or a serious issue depends on that relevance.

What brings my impartiality more into question, a t-shirt supporting the local Conservative candidate in the riding in which my court room sits, or a t-shirt supporting Wan Azizah Wan, an Ismaili politician from Malaysia, 13 000km away from where I'm sitting? Clearly, the former.

Think of the rules around recusal. There's always some firm tie (money, family, romantic, sexual, political, prior ruling as part of judicial dispute resolution) that can be leveraged and possibly affect the case, right? None of those exist in this context, so all this judge did was violate any oath of professionalism he took with his association. If it cannot be tied back to a possible ruling, then it's no different than an opinion about a hockey team, or a food preference. It's an opinion, but it's an irrelevant one, for the purposes of discussing impartiality.

Comment: I like your 'handle' of looking for solutions.  I wish everyone who made a complaint would also have to suggest a solution. More funding is just about the only way to make class sizes smaller.  (And anyone who says class sizes don't matter should try to substitute teach in an elementary classroom with 33 3rd graders and one teacher - not the home school dream scenario).  Local school districts, run by local school boards, determine how to spend the money from the state.  Every district has a budget committee that the public at large can serve on, to get a better understanding of and make decisions about school budgets.  I would encourage you to join a public school budget committee.  Or at least talk to a budget committee member to get their perspective about what real fiscal challenges school districts face.

Comment: The reason catch and release exists is to provide access while preserving the resource.  You are correct that when gear is too light (rod, line, tippet, etc.), it takes much longer to land them.  My guess would be that this increased stress, lactic acid buildup, etc., increases mortality as much as incorrect handling.

That said, nearly all of the catch and release anglers I know use appropriate gear.  They enjoy their pursuit, and they want it to be available to them and their children forever.  They know that taking care increases the fishes chance of successfully spawning, while also increasing their chance at catching it again later.

Comment: This is a digression.  But I note that if example, almost never criticized, determines what is appropriate, then numbers of members of Congress and legislators have done this for centuries.  A significant fraction of legislators have done this, and it was not controversial for most of that history.  Presidents and Governors in formal speech, even before legislatures, have done the same, as has the President Pro Tem of the Senate (i.e. the Vice President).  It may now be politically incorrect on the left to do this, but it is not outside our tradition, and it is probably done because politicians believe it is net boon to their political support - whatever their theology may be.  I expect it to continue until and unless most voters start objecting to it.

Comment: I bet there is one thing they are not talking about:

The money set aside for Legislator Salary Padding.  

Legislators use an obscure  IRS code and choose to get "reimbursed" for lodging and food at the federal per diem rate-regardless of expenses- rather than at the state per diem rate used by the governor and other state employees. During the regular session in Juneau,  legislators get about $235/day for lodging and food. For example, a recent House report shows that Rep. Reinbold paid $850 in rent plus $100 in utilities, a total of $950/month. Rep. Vasquez paid $650 in rent, plus $100 in utilities, a total of $750. Both legislators received about $235 per day, or $7,000 per month for room and board, meaning that each of them is receiving over $6,000- tax free-  per month above actual lodging expenses.

Comment: If the driver was proceeding northbound near Potter Marsh, then the sun would be in her eyes at 10:30pm.  I just drove this stretch of road watching the sun setting at 11:00pm. Lots of binoculars and cameras and not a whole lot of peripheral awareness. Whatever the case may be, it's an unfortunate accident.   Keep one eye on the road and one on the shoulder!  I feel safer driving the Arm in a blizzard than I do driving on a sunny summer's eve.

Comment: Nonsense. 
I say that having retired quite comfortably at 52 from 15 years as partner in a small corp. We issued bonuses, never dividends. Kept little excess capital inside. Only money ever borrowed was shareholder loans. All passive income was interest, mostly on contract deposits. We did our riskier investments outside the corporation. We had low accounting costs, personally and corporately. Importantly, we slept well. 
What really bothers me about all this tax business the last few years is the growth of complication, both personally and corporately.  A primary goal of tax reform ought to be simplification. On the govt side a metric might be 1000 less employees at CRA because taxes have become simpler. On the other side, we want business to be able to report lower accounting costs and the rarely monetized compliance costs. In other words, that dentist ought to be more predisposed to do his own taxes; they should be that easy.

Comment: Catholic and Protestant school boards were created for Ontario in the BNA act. At the time Catholics were a persecuted minority in Ontario, as the Orange Lodge controlled much of the province's government. The Ontario Catholic school boards were a quid pro quo for Protestant school boards in Quebec. Well into the 1960's (Protestant) religious education was part of the public school curriculum in Ontario. Jews and other religious minorities were excused from these classes.

What happened in the 1980's was not the creation of Catholic boards, but the extension of funding for secondary schools to those boards. 

Quebec and Newfoundland have now changed from religious-based funding. Given that Catholics are no longer a persecuted minority, it's probably time to abandon the discriminatory practice of funding religious schools for just one group.

In actual fact, most orders arrive ahead of time. Best ever was two days (used free seven day shipping, ordered early Monday morning, delivered Tuesday aft.). That was a bit of an anomaly. More common is three to four days. It is the rare order shipped from Amazon.ca that does not arrive before the scheduled arrival date given at the package tracking site. From my standpoint the relationship between Amazon.ca and Canada Post seems to be working very well.

Comment: I was in and around large-corp boards for a very long time.  Most of the members were selected to be supportive of the one or two people who made all the decisions.  These star chamber power centers always chose other board members expressly for their propensity to fall in line.  I remember a now-prominent woman board member of a huge company who gave an unexpected speech one day, to the effect that, "this company has lost the right to exist because of its incompetence...." and she resigned.  It was one of a very few such shows of character and courage I ever saw in that context.  

I do not know whether I have a useful point to make even now.  Perhaps it is that being a member of a board, in and of itself, only makes you a good candidate for another such position.  It gives you no power or influence.    So what is all the fuss?  How about having more women starting companies and trying out other women on their own boards and committees?

Comment: What worries me however with this article is that we have not been taken into confidence on what the substantive arguments for or against are between the AG and SARS' own interpretation of the SARS mandate. 

A layman's analysis of the SARS ACT seems to empower SARS and the Commisioner with determination of terms and conditions of employment & only refers to Ministers approval in so far as appointment of staff. Unless a regulation was signed which regulated how SARS and the Minister determine terms, conditions & appointment and expressely requires the Commissioner to get Minister's approval, the Commissioner may well be within his right to challenge the AG's finding. It is possible that the ACT has ommisions that màke this determination vague.

Granted good governance requires matters relating to remuneration to be subject to approval by oversight functions. The SARS Board has only advisory powers to the Minister and the Commissioner, which means Minister exercises oversight.

Comment: Hello, Trid. To me, the difference between civil and not is the difference between "I disagree" and "You're a moron." When it's that blatant, it's easy, but the trickier ones are the over-generalized passive aggressive comments like, "Liberals are morally bankrupt," or "Conservatives don't care about the poor."  I think, more often than not, comments like that are just a way to take a shot at the other poster while pretending it isn't a personal judgment.

What I try to do -- usually, but not always successfully -- is think of the person I'm in conversation with as an individual instead of as representing some class or group. I try not to presume more than is in their message and just speak to their point. I find when I do that it's easier to have a respectful conversation.

That's my goal anyway. But, being human, I'll admit to being a work in progress!

Comment: "retraining a worker who's a decade from retirement may not be the best use of public funds (or that worker's time) — especially because rampant ageism makes it harder for older workers to find jobs in new fields even when they do get training."

I strongly disagree.  A worker who's a decade from retirement has ten years of productivity available to his employer and likely a strong work ethic.  The public funds expended to provide public assistance and subsidized health care at least cancel out the cost of the retraining.  Especially if you count the fact that a working person pays taxes that help pay for all those services to youth just preparing for the workforce.  

But what pains me is that the author's cavalier attitude toward older workers allowed her to gloss over the fact that age discrimination is rampant in this country.  Addressing that is something all candidates for president should be talking about.

Comment: When I divide the pop. growth in the Lower Mainland by housing completions, I get a number that is substantially lower than the average household size (~2.1 against ~2.6). Perhaps it's worth checking this for the GTA as well? For the Lower Mainland, this data suggests that ample supply is being made. The need then is to examine whether the supply being built meets shelter demand (would require legislation/ incentives to drive building of units with more bedrooms), as well as to assess whether this "demand" is being driven by demand for something other than demand for shelter (which has a lot less to do with population growth than it does with speculation [either foreign or domestic]).

It's worth noting that the population growth rate in the Lower Mainland was larger 10-20 years ago, when prices were relatively flat. And that rents here, even with recent increases, are less than the carrying costs for owning (very true for detached houses). This does not suggest demand for shelter.

Comment: Clearly the Conference Board remains in the past. Its article is all about GDP and economic wealth. Far more important then economic factors, as Japan has shown, is living conditions. Japan, while a basket case economically remains tied with Sweden for best place to live, in developed countries. There is an economic factor that correlates with living conditions. That is income inequality. Top 20% of earners divided by bottom 20%. The lower the ratio the better the living conditions. And it correlates over 23 developed countries. Thus it should not be ignored. 

However a stronger economy is good for business. It is superficially good for the wealthy - makes them wealthier. That is hard to beat since that has been our theme song for generations. It will take time to sell the idea that everyone gains from reduced income inequality - quality of life increases. That is in contrast with increase in GDP, the wealthy gain in wealth but not in living conditions.

How to decrease inequality.

Comment: There is absolutely nothing wrong with the Grass Creek development.  I live about a mile away (near Cheney Lake), and walk my dogs through Begich Middle and through/around Grass Creek on a very regular basis.  I have long been impressed by the pride of ownership evident in the nicely landscaped and sparkling clean development, and the community center where there are always kids gathered to play.  This spills over into Begich as well, and I'm consistently amazed by the number of community kids running on the track or playing basketball on evenings and weekends, just enjoying the outdoors and doing their thing.  Having lived in the lower 48 I thought I could spot Section 8 housing from a mile away, but I was surprised when I learned GC is a low/mixed income development.  Honestly, the place looks more well kept than many of the single family homes (300 - 500k) in our subdivision, where we've got  "middle class" folks with blue tarps and junked cars on their lawns.

Comment: Hard for me to understand why such a respected lawyer as Tracey Lindberg, uses the term 'nation-to-nation' to explain the legal relationship between Canadians of Indigenous ancestry and the government of Canada. 

An Indigenous nation of Canadians in this context means, a group of Canadians who share a common history beyond their common history with other Canadians. So what is the other nation in the nation-to-nation relationship? The government of Canada cannot represent one group of Canadians to the exclusion of other Canadians. It's a clear conflict of interest and a violation of their duty in trust to treat all Canadians without passion or prejudice.

Canada is a country (land mass) and the people living their of common cause and citizenship make up the nation (people) of Canadians. Might as well make the argument the government of Canada has a duty to advocate for Canadians in one province to the exclusion of Canadians in another province.

Comment: Reading this article and the ensuing (and largely predictable) commentary, I am struck yet again by how many "rules-driven" (aka "legalistic") people fail to grasp the consequences of Goedel's Incompleteness Theorem.  It is impossible to formulate a set of logical propositions which are both complete and consistent.  If you want consistency, you must sacrifice completeness.  All lawmakers and law-enforcers need to understand this limitation of human logic.  

Jesus Christ repeatedly pointed his questioners back to the underlying principles, rather than allowing Himself to be trapped in the minutiae of interpretations that sensibly will vary from case to case.

Dr Patterson has shown us one serious contradiction in GC Working Policy.  There are probably others.  In these cases the wisest course is to remove the contradiction, and permit lower-level entities to determine the appropriate action on a case-by-case basis.

Has God tasked us to resolve all contradictions in this life?

Comment: One of the areas where universities have traditionally come up short is in connecting the disciplines with real-world career possibilities; particularly those possibilities the student might not automatically think of or spontaneously connect with their training.  Unless one is in a business program, there are few nudges to think entrepreneurially.  This is perhaps most especially true in the social sciences, humanities and arts.  

We can't all become profs like the people who taught us, but that doesn't mean our only two choices are fitting into a pre-determined degree-to-job slot, or doing something that makes us regret what we spent that money and those income-earning years on.  Learning to think deeply about a field, or generally, is applicable to a lot of careers.  Programs need to spend a little more effort in showing students the possibilities, rather than leaving them to fend for themselves.

Comment: You pay Comcast to access the internet at the given speed. Thus you expect all content on the internet to be available at the fastest speed their servers can handle, up to the 100 Mbps. 

The FCC wants to change the rules to say that Comcast can still charge you for 100Mbps, then can actually throttle any content provider they wish. This means even if content provider A has servers that can handle 100Mbps upload speeds so that you can download at the speed for which you paid, Comcast can throttle the content provider A to 10Mbps  because it competes with Comcast's own content, which they still provide at 100Mbps. Thus you paid for 100Mbps but your favorite content provider A only downloads at 10Mbps. You as the consumer now do not get what you paid for. 

Considering Comcast owns NBC Universal, they have tons of content that they can favor which stifles their competition and only gives you that promised speed IF you use Comcast's content.

Comment: The current bill will drastically cut medicaid. It will also make it so that insurance companies, although they won't technically be barring people with pre-existing conditions like before the ACA, they will be able to raise their premiums drastically for those individuals, making it unaffordable, and thus unavailable. Many people will be back to that terrifying spot of not knowing whether or not they can afford the necessary treatment to survive. Many Europeans find it unfathomable that an accident or cancer diagnosis could lead to bankrupcy, whereas, sadly, in the US, that's seen as just the way things are. Pure capitalism does not mix well with healthcare, as people's quality of life, and even lives themselves, hang in the balance. Even if the new bill is trying to keep the government from intervening too much with people's healthcare or insurance, the way the transition's being handled and its current wording will impose far more control & power over people with health conditions.

Reduce the size of the military (bring the soldiers home, we could use them on the border), but I agree with you that the federal government could be reduced by half and we the people would become freer and more able to innovate the country out of the truly awful economic mess that is looming due to the last two administrations' profligate spending. Reducing taxes on corporations would free up a lot of small-business corporations to start up and expand, also creating jobs.

But folks like Frank don't like the idea of people being free to do what they want with their money they earned. They prefer the power taxation allows them to wield over others.

Whether he's throwing balls to receivers who are well covered, or scrambling into pressure, Trevor is as much of a problem as the O-line.  If opposing defenses stack the box with 7 or 8 dudes, it's up to Trevor to throw them out of that defense.  He has to get rid of the ball quicker and more accurately.  If he can't do that, then it doesn't matter who is playing on the O-line.  He's as much to blame, if not slightly more, than the O-line.

Comment: A few things to consider for anyone in their position: 

1. You may not have the child when you expect or not at all and may need fertility treatments that cost a lot of money
2. Make sure you have adequate disability and life insurance -both private and don't rely on work related insurance alone. 
3. Maximize your accident benefits- the likelihood of an accident with commuting is likely higher than those that don't rely on vehicles to get to work. You will eat through the current standard benefits in no time and will pay out of pocket for the rest
4. Spending on entertainment etc seems pretty extravagant.
5. Cut back on expenses where you can and build a rainy day fund, you never know when you might need it.
6. A job loss can happen to anyone at any time and with it goes, the pension. 
7. If you have to be working at 2 jobs each just to make ends meet, it suggests you are not living within your means.
8. Its good to start thinking of retirement, but a lot can change from age 29-60.

Comment: Ms. Isley,  The reservoir is the county's attempt to correct the mistakes made by piping the irrigation ditches, causing wells to go dry.  The county is now involved with injection wells in their vain attempt to recharge the shallow aquifer, like spitting in the ocean. 

The Dungeness Basin has been identified by DOE as one of 16 in Washington State that is considered "water-critical:" with a shortage of water for existing needs.

The county was aware of this, they were warned by the USGS, Drost, 1983 report, that interrupting the irrigation system would result in a "20 foot drop in the shallow aquifer, lower heads, greater pumping cost and several well could go dry."  Well, that's exactly what happened.

Every effort by this county and all the Non-Governmental Agencies (NGOs) has been to dry up the area in the name of "conservation" while continuing to develop on an already over appropriated water resource.

I agree, the reservoir is not the answer and neither is a dam.

Not necessarily because "wages have stagnated or gone down for a decade," but because the people you call "Joe Public" continue to confuse "need" and "want." It's often NOT a matter of how much money they spend, but WHAT they spend it on.  On this same page, another commenter complains that it was difficult to afford "basic day-to-day requirements," and in the next paragraph, complains about the high cost of a week of summer camp.  Summer camp is NOT a basic requirement.   Joe Public "gets screwed"??  Suggestion to Joe: look in the mirror. 

I admit it: "anecdotal" evidence. Your paragraph beginning, "So: as interest rates rise..." is simply a flight of fancy, because none of what you state has happened yet!  No, Canadians' spending didn't come "crashing down"... "as in 2008" because interest rates rose. In fact, 2008 recession occurred during a long-term rate decline (over 10% in mid-1990s; 6.5% in 2008!)

Rest assured, everything Con-quer said is not doomsaying, hypothetical, or cynicism... it is a literal and logical extrapolation of what Canadian's experience on every front on a daily basis.

Comment: I read your letter before my morning coffee.  Your comment about doing more with less is a falacy.  Doctors, Nurses, therapists and technicians of all kinds have the right to expect salaries that reward them for the years they spent in school and other training and the experiences they have from years of practice.  Sutures cost the same, no matter if you are placing them in a Single Payer patient or one whose care is paid for by a for profit health care plan.  Hospital rooms cost a lot to build supply and staff.  The amount that people think they can save by eliminating profits are in the single digits of percents and are guesses.  If you saved two or three or four percent at your job, you would only be able to do a little more.  There are not enough savings that might be had by doing away with private insurance to fill the current gap between available care and demand.  The theory that there would be is right out of Reaganomics.

Comment: There are 3 intertwined issues in this article:
1) Borrowing to invest. Something many investors could do, but most should not do.
2) Market timing. He did well on the buy decision, but only time will tell if this is a good time to sell. A better approach for most investors (those mere mortals that are not prescient or lucky) is to pick an asset allocation that is compatible with their risk tolerance and timeline and re-balance back to it periodically
3) How to react to rumours about investment tax changes. If an investor that is not heavily leveraged cashes out now to avoid possible CG tax increase, what do they do with the cash? Will they really be able to reinvest for an increased future return considering the tax they will pay now? It's possible to run some scenarios on various guesses of tax rate changes, but just selling on a hunch is not the way good investors  investors stay successful.

Comment: I take it that you are specifically attributing your assertion "Crammer's book of Common Prayer was pretty much just a translation of the Catholic Sarum Rite" to Adrian Fortescue, "The Mass: A Study of the Roman Liturgy?" 

Haven't read Fortescue in decades, but this notion strikes me as absurd. 

I challenge you to provide citations. The book is available on linefor easy electronic searching.

Ten minutes of my research revealed that, quite to the contrary, Fortescue expresses the view that the ordinary of the Sarum liturgy was essentially the ordinary of the Roman liturgy with a few variation in the order of things (in the second edition [1914] please see page 202ff.) More to the point, on page 205, footnote 1, Fortescue expresses the exact opposite view--the the reformed Anglican liturgy is not related to the Sarum rite, which had become wide spread in England just prior to the Protestant Reformation.

Comment: It's an imperfect platform. I've had only two comments removed, protested, and Civil Comments agreed they were absolutely within the guidelines. A third, which was a response to another comment, was also taken down along with that comment, although both went back up about an hour later, indicating that they might be monitoring things more closely. The comment I responded to was something I disagreed with, but it was stated in civil language, as was my response.

The shortcoming is that some people will just vote down comments they disagree with. What might work is if Civil Comments checked to see which posters are doing this. I received an email from them awhile back saying I wasn't voting down enough comments, but it was a bot message. I responded and they looked at my history and only found two I'd approved that they considered out of bounds. So there is some checking on that end.

It's a new and good idea that needs some tweaking.  Unfortunately sometimes good comments go away
